body:
> > Hi @fzoepffel
> > Good to see the PR, I think you accidentally added your virtual environments to the commit, you can add a the venv folder to .gitignore and remove it.
> > Thanks
> 
> Removed the venv folder and added it to gitignore

there is still one other venv folder there.

> > > Hi @fzoepffel
> > > Good to see the PR, I think you accidentally added your virtual environments to the commit, you can add a the venv folder to .gitignore and remove it.
> > > Thanks
> > 
> > 
> > Removed the venv folder and added it to gitignore
> 
> there is still one other venv folder there.

Two even :D Missed those ones. Now it should be correct

> > The remaining conflicts were just resolved. Now the PR should be ready to merge. Further validation(e.g. empty inputs, differing dimensions of imaginary and real inputs, etc.) and minor bug fixes like the handling of only zero input matrices will come in a separate PR for the integrated python tests. Currently the workflows are waiting for this PR are awaiting approval. Hopefully the integrationtests that were failing before will succeed now. We are assuming that these integration tests are not related to us. Please let us know if you think differently.
> 
> Hi @fzoepffel
> 
> The code passes all tests, great.
> 
> I think your codeformatter ran in many of the PR files. Can we revert this? We try to avoid formatting existing files (even if the format is wrong) unless we do major changes.

I just saw. I am a little unsure however, how I can revert this. When I run the formatter (which I configured to use the CodeStyle_eclipse.xml file) it does not necessarily reverse to what it was before. Or would I have to go over all the commits and reverse the parts where only code is formatted?

> > > The remaining conflicts were just resolved. Now the PR should be ready to merge. Further validation(e.g. empty inputs, differing dimensions of imaginary and real inputs, etc.) and minor bug fixes like the handling of only zero input matrices will come in a separate PR for the integrated python tests. Currently the workflows are waiting for this PR are awaiting approval. Hopefully the integrationtests that were failing before will succeed now. We are assuming that these integration tests are not related to us. Please let us know if you think differently.
> > 
> > 
> > Hi @fzoepffel
> > The code passes all tests, great.
> > I think your codeformatter ran in many of the PR files. Can we revert this? We try to avoid formatting existing files (even if the format is wrong) unless we do major changes.
> 
> I just saw. I am a little unsure however, how I can revert this. When I run the formatter (which I configured to use the CodeStyle_eclipse.xml file) it does not necessarily reverse to what it was before.

The files was just not formatted before. Not everyone formats the files, and we have some legacy/old code that we would rather have refer to the original authors rather than change the format of it. Therefore i have configured my IDE only for format on request not automatically.

A concrete way of handling it is a bit more tricky. I suggest going back through commits and figuring out which commit did the formatting, and then revert the formatting without breaking the changes that you wanted to do. There probably is a smarter way, but I am unaware of such.
This feature needs more thought and testing before it is ready for merging. I will leave it for the next release. @j143

> > > > The remaining conflicts were just resolved. Now the PR should be ready to merge. Further validation(e.g. empty inputs, differing dimensions of imaginary and real inputs, etc.) and minor bug fixes like the handling of only zero input matrices will come in a separate PR for the integrated python tests. Currently the workflows are waiting for this PR are awaiting approval. Hopefully the integrationtests that were failing before will succeed now. We are assuming that these integration tests are not related to us. Please let us know if you think differently.
> > > 
> > > 
> > > Hi @fzoepffel
> > > The code passes all tests, great.
> > > I think your codeformatter ran in many of the PR files. Can we revert this? We try to avoid formatting existing files (even if the format is wrong) unless we do major changes.
> > 
> > 
> > I just saw. I am a little unsure however, how I can revert this. When I run the formatter (which I configured to use the CodeStyle_eclipse.xml file) it does not necessarily reverse to what it was before.
> 
> The files was just not formatted before. Not everyone formats the files, and we have some legacy/old code that we would rather have refer to the original authors rather than change the format of it. Therefore i have configured my IDE only for format on request not automatically.
> 
> A concrete way of handling it is a bit more tricky. I suggest going back through commits and figuring out which commit did the formatting, and then revert the formatting without breaking the changes that you wanted to do. There probably is a smarter way, but I am unaware of such.

The legacy had mainly been formatted in three commits. I reversed the hunks of these commits that were not related to our fft implementation. Since I had to do this for each file individually I added a "reverse formatting" commit for each file. Unfortunately two tests are failing now (see [**.functions.federated.monitoring.**,**.functions.federated.multitenant.**](https://github.com/apache/systemds/actions/runs/7837353259/job/21398216259?pr=1983#logs)
[**.component.c**.**](https://github.com/apache/systemds/actions/runs/7837353259/job/21398211615?pr=1983#logs)). 
I think that these tests have nothing to with our code though, as the FFT and IFFT functions still function as expected.

I am seeing the issue with shaded jar not available for signature while `mvn deploy` operation.

Could you approve this, fix?
LGTM. Great thanks

Hi @mufwan @jessicapriebe @fzoepffel 

 Welcome to SystemDS project ✨ 

yay! it's the 2000th Pull Request!
Hi @lachezar-n , welcome to SystemDS project ✨
LGTM. Thanks

Hi @lachezar-n , about the error you are facing could you share more details

please make sure to use Java 11, Spark 3.x
Thanks for following up on this @j143 to move the release along - much appreciated.

Comments from @Baunsgaard , there seem to be an issue with logging when the `SYSTEMDS_ROOT` is not set.

```log
Me:~/Downloads/systemds-3.2.0-bin$ cat test.dml


x = rand(rows = 1000, cols = 10, min = -10, max = 10)

x = ceil(x)

y = rand(rows = 1000, cols = 1, min = 0, max = 1)

y = round(y)


bias = lm(X=x, y=y)

print(sum(bias))

Me:~/Downloads/systemds-3.2.0-bin$ ./bin/systemds test.dml 
Calling the Direct Solver...
0.08330675008391338
SystemDS Statistics:
Total execution time:		0.053 sec.


Me:~/Downloads/systemds-3.2.0-bin$ unset SYSTEMDS_ROOT 
Me:~/Downloads/systemds-3.2.0-bin$ ./bin/systemds test.dml 
ERROR StatusLogger Reconfiguration failed: No configuration found for '55054057' at 'null' in 'null'
Calling the Direct Solver...
0.06721639156713015
SystemDS Statistics:
Total execution time:	
```

---

Notes on this issue elsewhere;

- https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LOG4J2-2901

- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66545546/error-statuslogger-reconfiguration-failed-no-configuration-found-for-73d16e93

  suggests to use;
    Use `log4j2.configurationFile` instead of `log4j.configurationFile`

- wrong config file also causes this issue;

    https://github.com/dadoonet/fscrawler/commit/69143d49ea9900a801a1e540fd8a9713d5197547 
    
    ![image](https://github.com/apache/systemds/assets/53068787/84ff24f4-11b8-44b4-aaed-005cecd54ffe)

    
- Discussion on a similar issue in the [log4j user mailing list](https://lists.apache.org/thread/okqymgvrddbj2qgp8d2f6o45o251cbq3)

    they suggest this plugin; https://github.com/apache/logging-log4j-transform/tree/main/log4j-transform-maven-shade-plugin-extensions

Hi @j143, thanks for the note about the execution, indeed I didn't know that Java 11 is required. 
EMR uses default Java version 8 so I made some changes to the the shell script to enforce using Java 11 on the Amazon cluster. I will post the changes as a new pull-request so the `run_systemds_script.sh` can execute successfully.
Closing because it is in other PR #2006

> Hi @mboehm7 / @Baunsgaard - perhaps we need to update here
> 
> https://github.com/apache/systemds/blob/eb29b2d5488d503c97c6b5845a7fffee9a225eed/bin/systemds#L95-L114
> 
> for `log4j2.configurationFile` instead of `log4j.configurationFile` or both (we shall check these)

I do not think this is the bug, but rather that we include to many dependency logging systems in our imported systems.

Also, I would prefer we do not change to the new logging file syntax(associated with the new versions).
I will try now to figure out if the newer versions works with our older logging files, otherwise we need to update all logging files, and call it a breaking dependency.

The problem is: 

```

Me:~/github/systemds/target/lib$ findjar slf4j.reload4j
(standard input):     0 Tue Feb 08 13:31:00 CET 2022 META-INF/maven/org.slf4j/slf4j-reload4j/
(standard input):  1153 Tue Feb 08 13:31:00 CET 2022 META-INF/maven/org.slf4j/slf4j-reload4j/pom.xml
(standard input):    62 Tue Feb 08 13:31:00 CET 2022 META-INF/maven/org.slf4j/slf4j-reload4j/pom.properties
slf4j-reload4j-1.7.36.jar
(standard input):     0 Mon Jan 08 17:55:00 CET 2024 org/slf4j/reload4j/
(standard input):     0 Mon Jan 08 17:55:00 CET 2024 META-INF/maven/org.slf4j/slf4j-reload4j/
(standard input):  5907 Mon Jan 08 17:55:00 CET 2024 org/slf4j/reload4j/Reload4jLoggerAdapter.class
(standard input):  2550 Mon Jan 08 17:55:00 CET 2024 org/slf4j/reload4j/Reload4jLoggerFactory.class
(standard input):  2928 Mon Jan 08 17:55:00 CET 2024 org/slf4j/reload4j/Reload4jMDCAdapter.class
(standard input):  1817 Mon Jan 08 17:55:00 CET 2024 org/slf4j/reload4j/Reload4jServiceProvider.class
(standard input):  2211 Mon Jan 08 17:55:00 CET 2024 META-INF/maven/org.slf4j/slf4j-reload4j/pom.xml
(standard input):    59 Mon Jan 08 17:55:00 CET 2024 META-INF/maven/org.slf4j/slf4j-reload4j/pom.properties
slf4j-reload4j-2.0.11.jar
```

We have two dependencies of slf4j 
where one or more of our other dependencies adds the older version.
Thanks for the update @j143 , I have now merged it with a minor commit on top that fixes the double dependency of slf4j

Hi @jessicapriebe thanks for addressing the comments.

If this changeset has the sufficient functionality, it can be merged.

And we can add subsequent improvements with new PRs. If possible, let's document the functionality and examples of these functions in an markdown file.

LGTM - thanks for the patch @lachezar-n. I resolved the merge conflicts (in the future please do not include the previous PR), and we should keep an eye open if the hard-coded `/usr/lib/jvm/jre-11` is always valid.

LGTM - thanks for finalizing this patch @Jaybit0. During the merge I fixed the size estimation for MCSR (number of attributes, differentiation into SparseRowScalar and SparseRowVector, capacity instead of size), and removed the materialized images as they are already outdated.

LGTM - thanks @e-strauss for the patch. During the merge I removed any commented code, fixed the wrong import (scala.Array.copy instead of System.arraycopy), fixed missing nnz updates, and cleaned up tabs vs spaces formatting issues.

LGTM - thanks for the patch @unical1988 and sorry for the delay. During the merge, I made the remaining modifications of the builtin function, and change the application test script so this builtin function is actually being called. Thanks.

LGTM - thanks for the patch @gogokotsev00 and team. During the merge, I moved the rewrite to a separate experimental rewrite which is not yet fully integrated (because I think it's not ready for that). The reason why you did not see your rewrite being applied as expected is that the transposes for folded into the generation of constant matrices (with flipped dimensions). By adding our special program block cut `while(FALSE){}` you can separate them and the tests fail with an unexpected number of transposes.
LGTM - thanks for the patch @sweetpellegrino. During the merge I removed the additional explain (as Arnab suggested), and fixed minor things in the added test (tabs vs spaces, and simplified types).

LGTM. Thanks for the patch @ReneEnjilian - during the merge I only moved the rewrite from dynamic to static rewrites (no size-based decision), tightened the source pattern (only if NOT is the only consumer), and simplified the test (single dml/R file).

LGTM - thanks for the patch @ReneEnjilian. I'll only change minor things during the merge. Overall, I think it might be a better choice for performance and separation to move the non-empty row iterators into the individual sparse block implementations, but I'll explore that once it's in.
Still debugging a bit, therefore it is marked as a draft.

@j143  Can you check if this fixes the issues for the release artifacts.

I have tested it with the released code, and it works for me.

If you set the SYSTEMDS_ROOT to the path of the unzipped bin release it works just like the other releases.
It also correctly detect the log4j files, in different configurations.
Taking over the merge of this PR in #2009
This PR is currently being merged in #2009
Cleaned up PR #1992

Thanks for completing ResNet implementation @MaximilianSchreff. Good work 👍🏽. 
In the future please avoid merging with the main branch, use rebase instead.
Merged

Thank you for the PR, 
While merging I have fixed the parallelization threads propagation through the compiler.
Future work is to fix the STFT, to integrate with the DML language again, since this did not merge nicely, and add documentation for the existence of FFT and STFT. in the dml language reference docs.

I have decided against merging this PR at the moment, since it is adding files some places not ideal.
If you want to clean it up @mufwan  then i will happily merge it.

Tasks:

1. Move the scripts into scripts/staging
2. Add documentation for how to run it inside the script, and what is expected.
3. Rebase the PR to not contain the changes for FFT

While merging the STFT is slightly changed and not hooked up to DML correctly,
The main issue was that one method got overloaded to take a long vs int as arguments to choose the version to call.

@j143 
I decided to merge it, because i have other things that depends on it, Feel free to comment on the Commit directly 387b6c1c8e472dde65a36e8f3fd22091054ed347
Hi @Baunsgaard -- I built the whl artifact and installed. And checked the logging doesn't seem to work as expected.

what do you mean with not working as intended?
if it is the nativeCodeLoader warning that you see then it is correct.

It is supposed to print the script output, isn't it?

>     model = l2svm(features, labels, verbose=False).compute()
>     logging.info(model)

it providing no output!

you should be able to make it if you set the logging level.

![image](https://github.com/apache/systemds/assets/9947148/e0926389-99cc-43cf-b21f-f86def00c712)

As you can see default behavior is nothing on info.

![image](https://github.com/apache/systemds/assets/9947148/a5195df1-60ab-4707-b9d3-54e15184a837)

While only warnings are printed.

If you want more info. you need to set level.

![image](https://github.com/apache/systemds/assets/9947148/a392f253-dffb-49b4-8dd3-19ca298e51c1)


Therefore everything is working as intended.
This PR is merged.
already published at https://pypi.org/project/systemds/

I'm not yet getting the problem here - the double buffering is used for all evictions and works for arbitrarily large arrays. Please make sure when changing it that the pipeline parallelism of serializing objects into byte arrays (with configurable array sizes) and the actual write is not jeopardized. Maybe avoid all reformatting and code duplication to focus the changes on the actual bug you have encountered. Thanks.
OK thanks for the clarification but for a general-purpose implementation, we should write it sequentially (no pool submit) because somebody might write the same byte array to the stream from outside.

> OK thanks for the clarification but for a general-purpose implementation, we should write it sequentially (no pool submit) because somebody might write the same byte array to the stream from outside.

We can clarify the code by not calling it a pool maybe?
Because it just makes the writing to this output stream asynchronous.
no, what I mean is that this code is incorrect - if somebody would allocate a large byte buffer, and repeatedly write this to the fastoutputstream, you get a race condition overwrite.

> no, what I mean is that this code is incorrect - if somebody would allocate a large byte buffer, and repeatedly write this to the fastoutputstream, you get a race condition overwrite.

ahh true.

LGTM - thanks for the patch @fzoepffel. During the merge, I just made minor adjustments (deleting the slicefinder.txt output file, simplifying the matrix comparison to a single call, and avoiding unnecessarily generating the R inputs).
LGTM - thanks for catching this issue @ReneEnjilian.

LGTM - thanks @fzoepffel for getting started on incremental slice line. During the merge, I left a TODO in the builtin to convert the new inputs and outputs to lists for easier collection and handling.
In future, please also use tabs over spaces in Java tests.
LGTM - thanks @evelina-gudauskayte for the patch and very detailed instructions. I'll try to setup my account and reconfigure the code next week (before merging it in).

LGTM - thanks for the patch @gghsu. This contribution already looked pretty good, I just made minor changes during the merge (formatting, unnecessary imports, and additional assertions to check that our rewrites simplify the function to a single comparison, which they do).
LGTM - thanks for the patch @e-strauss. During the merge I only fixes minor warnings and formatting issues.
LGTM - thanks @christinadionysio for getting started on this new component.

LGTM - thanks for the patch @canabdulla. The new builtin and tests very already pretty good, during the merge I just fixed some syntactic issues (tab indentation in Java code, and unnecessary free lines at the end of dml scripts).

Since we don't have access to the settings of the github repository, I looked around and found recent examples of Apache projects [1] using the same upload action v4. Apparently INFRA set it up globally already. So let's see and I'll give it a try.

[1] https://github.com/apache/nifi/pull/8808

LGTM - thanks for the additional improvement @e-strauss. I liked the ASCII art in the tests. During the merge I left a TODO comment to keep the information if a frame RDD is already aligned (so we only conditionally align if needed), and fixed the alignment of ASCII art (which where a bit distorted due to a mix of spaces and tabs).

Thanks @mboehm7  - I guessed it's simple way to understand the test case. When you say keep the information do mean store this information in the meta data field for each RDD or a function which checks for alignment, and than conditionally do the alignment.

I was thinking it would be very good to add a primitive in `FrameRDDConverterUtils` to check if the distributed collection is already 1K-aligned (by scanning and aggregating all block meta data), another one to convert it to 1K blocks (this is expensive because of shuffling), and then keep this information in the `FrameObject`'s DataCharacteristics (or subclass like FameCharacteristics) as a simple boolean. Whenever we then come to binary operations like the frame cbind, we can check this meta data and potentially resort back to a normal block append. Feel free to have a look into it if you're interested, but it's nice to have right now.
@dependabot squash and merge

Hi @cs-ally 

Thanks for the PR.

Before I go into details on the PR, I suggest you address the failing test cases in the Python API. The log indicates that they relate to your implementation.

Best regards
Sebastian

Hi @Nakroma 

The code looks great! The PR is nearly done.

Currently missing 

 - is backward test
 - and i am worried about multi return statements, where some layers return multiple variables. Would they work in the sequences?

best regards
Sebastian

Hey @Baunsgaard 

I actually completely forgot the backwards pass - sorry about that, it is added now!

About the multi returns - I wasn't 100% sure if returns for forward/backward passes are standardized. So I assumed here how it's handled in affine.py and relu.py is the standard - i.e. I check for a MultiReturn or a single node and return based on that. This might have to be changed depending on how the layer generator will work in the future though. Let me know if you think there is a better solution for that also.

Best,
Tarek

Great, i like the change. seems like you found a few bugs in the process.

Can we add a few more tests, where 

1. a multi return layer goes into a multi return layer, 
2. a TestLayerImp goes to Multi to multi 

and a few more variations.


Also can we verify that the layers get updated correctly on the backwards pass.

Once these are added I would consider the PR finished and ready for merging.
Closing to open new PR later
Closing to open new PR later

@mboehm7  
here is an example of adding builtin functions.
Thanks - LGTM and I'll let Tessa know that she can extend the TPCx-AI implementation accordingly.
@mboehm7 I have added the CP cost estimation that addapts to IO/compute bound operations, but couldn't spend enough time to get the SP estimation done following what we have discussed last time

Thanks for the changes, @Mayaryin and @ingunnaf. I will have a detailed look in the next days.
From the quick look, it is not the right idea to use an external library for caching. We want to build our own caching and cache management techniques for encoder intermediates. That would allow for a holistic integration to SystemDS' compiler and runtime infrastructure.

LGTM - thanks for the patch @gghsu. During the merge I fixed the builtin documentation (copy-paste error from selection), minor formatting issues (DML scripts use 2 space indentation), and added a method parameter to both new builtin functions. In following PRs it would be good to then add more methods (beyond nested loop) for efficient group-by and joins.
@Baunsgaard just pushed a commit that addresses more variations and the layer update during backwards pass.

> @Baunsgaard just pushed a commit that addresses more variations and the layer update during backwards pass.

Great. I will take a look tomorrow!

Hi! 

A good start of the PR. 
I suggest you try to squash your commits. And then afterwards rebase your changes on master. 

That should fix your merge conflict.

> Hi!
> 
> A good start of the PR. I suggest you try to squash your commits. And then afterwards rebase your changes on master.
> 
> That should fix your merge conflict.

It should be fixed now

Hi @ReneEnjilian 

The tests does not show up in the code coverage because the new package of tests you added is not run in GitHub actions. 
to enable it simply add a new element in the list on:

https://github.com/apache/systemds/blob/de91f669b87589d390a4c2804658210bb54ce1d7/.github/workflows/javaTests.yml#L57

or add a new line with the elements if you know your tests take a long time (10 minutes +)

The main benefit in this PR is when we perform replacement on a sparse matrix, and the output is dense. 

on a 10k x 10k 0.1 sparse matrix

After
```
java -jar target/systemds-3.3.0-SNAPSHOT-perf.jar 17 10000 10000 0.1 16
Profiling started
                        replaceZero,  132.883+-  9.335 ms,           
                         replaceOne,   59.612+-  3.295 ms,           
                         replaceNaN,   10.651+-  0.470 ms,
```

Before
```
java -jar target/systemds-3.3.0-SNAPSHOT-perf.jar 17 10000 10000 0.1 1
Profiling started
                        replaceZero,  228.727+- 11.965 ms,           
                         replaceOne,  163.212+-  4.993 ms,           
                         replaceNaN,   10.602+-  0.437 ms, 
```

LGTM - thanks for the patch @gghsu. During the merge, I added the default join method, renamed the new method to 'sort-merge', and let a few TODOs for future improvements (in a follow up project). In the future, please start a new PR instead of including the old commits (which creates unnecessary work for conflict resolution). Thanks.
closed manually because I forgot the sharp prefix in https://github.com/apache/systemds/commit/f81b76de742b1815f949c9d2aa9a13eb752499f2
just FYI, some tests are flaky when run in the cloud, therefore if the tests fail, and they are obviously not related to your changes no worries.

We added a unit test and a tests for multithreading. We attempted to test the cache via a dml script and a test dataset, but couldnt succeed. Our test results from the inner tests as well as the test data generation script and the dml scripts can be found in this repository: https://github.com/Mayaryin/systemds_test_data
